Incident Investigation
Aztalan Bio investigates incidents that result in, or could reasonably result in, a release of a regulated substance. Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.

Compliance Audits
The facility will conduct audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. The audit will include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.

Accident History
The facility has not had any accidents reportable for the regulated substance under RMP. 

Emergency Response Program
Aztalan Bio maintains a written Emergency Response Program. The purpose of the Emergency Response Plan is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The Emergency Response Plan addresses aspects of emergency response, including medical treatment, evacuation plans, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. In addition, Aztalan Bio maintains, inspects, and tests emergency response equipment. Employees receive training as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. We work with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan. The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As owner of this facility, Aztalan Bio will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility. As it updates procedures affecting RMP, modifications will be submitted.

of the facility. The most recent PHA update was completed in August 2023.

Aztalan Bio keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, and piping & instrumentation diagrams.

Operating Procedures and Training
Aztalan Bio maintains written procedures that address process operations during normal, emergency, startup and shutdown situations. The facility develops and implements a training program for its employees involved in facility operations. 

Contractors
Aztalan Bio requires its on-site contractors to attend a training program and to follow Aztalan Bio safe work practices. 

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
Aztalan Bio conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) as may be required for its facility modifications that require a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.

Mechanical Integrity
The facility's mechanical integrity program includes inspections and equipment testing to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems, and controls in a safe operational condition.

Management of Change
The facility's management of change (MOC) program reviews proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, an

ker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire. Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hours with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations  therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides. The loadout area also has a quick drain system that will convey spills to secondary containment of the tank farm dike. For this scenario passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire.  RMP Comp was used to determine the alternate distance to endpoint (0.1 miles), the model results are provided as part of this documentation. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) which incorporates which incorporates 2017  2021 American Community Survey Data. Data was unavailable for a radius of 0.1 miles so the 0.2 miles was used. Public receptor information (i.e. schools, hospitals) was obtained using Google Earth. No environmental receptors are affected by an alternate release of denaturant.  

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Aztalan Bio has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, process safety management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations.

Employee Participation
Aztalan Bio has developed an employee participation program. All process safety information, incident investigations, compliance audits, operation procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operation personnel at any time.

Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information
Aztalan Bio purchased this facility as part of an asset purchase agreement in June 2022. Aztalan Bio was unable to identify a PHA completed by the prior owner

ighbors. In addition, the Emergency Response Plan is used to familiarize local emergency response personnel with the types of material handled and internal emergency response procedures.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled
The Aztalan Bio facility is a 110 million gallon per year nameplate corn-based dry-grind fractionation denatured ethanol fuel production plant. Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through fermentation and distillation process.

The regulated substance stored at the facility is natural gasoline, which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.

Worst Case Scenarios:
1.	Flammable Mixture (Denaturant):  The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant.  Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment off site. Denaturant is stored in one (1) 105,200-gallon steel tank in the facility tank farm. The tank is located within a berm containment structure.  A worst-case SDS was used to determine RMP applicability. The SDS lists several RMP-applicable constituents; however, it is assumed the entire mixture as Pentane. The worst-case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, 614,158 pounds, causing a vapor cloud explosion.  RMP Comp was used to determine the worst-case distance to endpoint (0.7 miles), the model results are provided as part of this documentation. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling System (CAPS) which incorporates 2017  2021 American Community Survey Data. Public receptor information (i.e. schools, hospitals) was obtained using Google Earth. No environmental receptors are affected by a worst case release of denaturant.

Aztalan Bio LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of ClonBio, was established as a Wisconsin Limited Liability Company to acquire the Jefferson facility from Valero Renewable Fuels in June 2022. Since acquiring the facility, Aztalan Bio has invested significantly to bring the bioethanol plant up to the groups standard based on the Pannonia Bio facility in Europe, with startup planned for October 1st, 2023. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The Aztalan Bio facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of natural gasoline, a regulated flammable mixture, above the threshold quantity, and the following policies relate to this regulated substance.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Aztalan Bio is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public. Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Using the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of equipment, and the training of our personnel, Aztalan Bio is minimizing the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.

In the event that a release does occur, the facility's emergency response actions are described in its Emergency Response Plan. The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e., law enforcement, fire, and rescue departments, emergency medical services, hospital and government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affected ne
